hawaiian_text: A pau ka pule ‘ana a Nāmakaokapāo‘o, i ia wā i  ‘o‘oki ai ‘o Puali‘i i ke ko‘ilipi i luna pono o  Nāmakaokapāo‘o, e ho‘ohuli aku ā nā ‘oi o ke ko‘i  iā Puali‘i, moku ke po‘o, a ‘ōlelo mai i kahi ‘ē. Pane  mai ke po‘o o Puali‘i iā Nāmakaokapāo‘o: “Aloha  ‘oe, e Nāmakaokapāo‘o.” Lālau akula ‘o   Nāmakaokapāo‘o i ke po‘o o Puali‘i a kiola akula i  kai o Waipouli, he ana ma kahakai o Honouliuli, ‘o  kona loa, ‘elima mile ka loa.
gpt-4o-mini_translation: A pau ka pule ‘ana a Nāmakaokapāo‘o, i ia wā i  ‘o‘oki ai ‘o Puali‘i i ke ko‘ilipi i luna pono o  Nāmakaokapāo‘o, e ho‘ohuli aku ā nā ‘oi o ke ko‘i  iā Puali‘i, moku ke po‘o, a ‘ōlelo mai i kahi ‘ē. Pane  mai ke po‘o o Puali‘i iā Nāmakaokapāo‘o: “Aloha  ‘oe, e Nāmakaokapāo‘o.” Lālau akula ‘o   Nāmakaokapāo‘o i ke po‘o o Puali‘i a kiola akula i  kai o Waipouli, he ana ma kahakai o Honouliuli, ‘o  kona loa, ‘elima mile ka loa.
gpt-4o-mini_commentary:
**Paragraph 9:**  
• In this passage, we see Nāmakaokapāo'o in a moment of transition or change. It begins by describing the conclusion of a pule (prayer or chant) after which Puali'i (Child/Descendant of Chiefs) asserts his dominance by ‘o‘oki (to cut), showcasing a common practice in Hawaiian culture where ritual and physical action converge.  
  – The phrase “a pau ka pule ‘ana” indicates that the prayer's ending serves as a significant ceremonial marker, setting the stage for subsequent events.   
• The act of ‘o‘oki by Puali‘i, who is noted to ‘ho‘ohuli’ (turn over) the ko‘i (adze) that had been positioned over Nāmakaokapāo‘o, suggests assertiveness and power. This action could symbolize altering control over the new context in which Nāmakaokapāo'o finds himself, possibly hinting at cultural shifts from traditional values to newer forms of human interactions.  
  – The terminology “ko’i lipi” (a sharp tool) may also imply deeper meanings related to craftsmanship and the importance of skill in Hawaiian society; the sharpness of the ko‘i parallels the clarity or decisiveness in decision-making.  
• “Moku ke po‘o” conveys the notion of Puali'i's head (po‘o) being cut off or demolished, with 'moku' meaning to break or cut; this could imply a significant loss of stature, identity, or power—themes central to many Hawaiian narratives. The introduction of the greeting “Aloha ‘oe, e Nāmakaokapāo‘o” by Puali'i signifies an intimate, albeit complex relationship, where that phrase can denote both affection and a form of finality.  
  – 'Aloha' is a term rich with meanings like love, compassion, peace, and mercy; it is a greeting that signifies connections but can also symbolize parting.  
• In the actions and interactions that follow, we witness the physicality of Nāmakaokapāo'o, who “lālau akula” (seizes) the head of Puali'i and subsequently thrusts it to the waters of Waipouli—a location known for its beauty and cultural significance.  
  – Waipouli (Water of the Little) and Honouliuli (dark bay) are both noted places, suggesting a transition from land to sea, which is significant in Hawaiian cosmology where the ocean embodies the source of life and strength. The distance of “he ana ma kahakai o Honouliuli, ‘o kona loa, ‘elima mile ka loa” (stretching along the shore of Honouliuli, its length being five miles) evokes a sense of vast separation, possibly symbolizing the cultural chasm between the characters and the loss of traditional societal values.  
  – This can be seen as an allegory for the destruction of natural beauty and heritage as represented by the strong, young boy who in his recklessness enacts change that is irreversible; the number five (’elima) traditionally symbolizes the five main islands of Hawai'i and can be connecting to broader themes of connectivity and disruption within and among the islands.  
• Overall, this passage highlights the complexities of relationships and the transformative nature of actions in Hawaiian cultural storytelling, serving as a reminder of the intertwined nature of spirituality, physical space, and personal identity in the narrative. It reflects the tension between traditional values, the consequences of individual actions, and the impact of evolving societal norms during the ‘Ai Kapu era and beyond.
raw_response:
<translation>A pau ka pule ‘ana a Nāmakaokapāo‘o, i ia wā i  ‘o‘oki ai ‘o Puali‘i i ke ko‘ilipi i luna pono o  Nāmakaokapāo‘o, e ho‘ohuli aku ā nā ‘oi o ke ko‘i  iā Puali‘i, moku ke po‘o, a ‘ōlelo mai i kahi ‘ē. Pane  mai ke po‘o o Puali‘i iā Nāmakaokapāo‘o: “Aloha  ‘oe, e Nāmakaokapāo‘o.” Lālau akula ‘o   Nāmakaokapāo‘o i ke po‘o o Puali‘i a kiola akula i  kai o Waipouli, he ana ma kahakai o Honouliuli, ‘o  kona loa, ‘elima mile ka loa.</translation>

<commentary>**Paragraph 9:**  
• In this passage, we see Nāmakaokapāo'o in a moment of transition or change. It begins by describing the conclusion of a pule (prayer or chant) after which Puali'i (Child/Descendant of Chiefs) asserts his dominance by ‘o‘oki (to cut), showcasing a common practice in Hawaiian culture where ritual and physical action converge.  
  – The phrase “a pau ka pule ‘ana” indicates that the prayer's ending serves as a significant ceremonial marker, setting the stage for subsequent events.   
• The act of ‘o‘oki by Puali‘i, who is noted to ‘ho‘ohuli’ (turn over) the ko‘i (adze) that had been positioned over Nāmakaokapāo‘o, suggests assertiveness and power. This action could symbolize altering control over the new context in which Nāmakaokapāo'o finds himself, possibly hinting at cultural shifts from traditional values to newer forms of human interactions.  
  – The terminology “ko’i lipi” (a sharp tool) may also imply deeper meanings related to craftsmanship and the importance of skill in Hawaiian society; the sharpness of the ko‘i parallels the clarity or decisiveness in decision-making.  
• “Moku ke po‘o” conveys the notion of Puali'i's head (po‘o) being cut off or demolished, with 'moku' meaning to break or cut; this could imply a significant loss of stature, identity, or power—themes central to many Hawaiian narratives. The introduction of the greeting “Aloha ‘oe, e Nāmakaokapāo‘o” by Puali'i signifies an intimate, albeit complex relationship, where that phrase can denote both affection and a form of finality.  
  – 'Aloha' is a term rich with meanings like love, compassion, peace, and mercy; it is a greeting that signifies connections but can also symbolize parting.  
• In the actions and interactions that follow, we witness the physicality of Nāmakaokapāo'o, who “lālau akula” (seizes) the head of Puali'i and subsequently thrusts it to the waters of Waipouli—a location known for its beauty and cultural significance.  
  – Waipouli (Water of the Little) and Honouliuli (dark bay) are both noted places, suggesting a transition from land to sea, which is significant in Hawaiian cosmology where the ocean embodies the source of life and strength. The distance of “he ana ma kahakai o Honouliuli, ‘o kona loa, ‘elima mile ka loa” (stretching along the shore of Honouliuli, its length being five miles) evokes a sense of vast separation, possibly symbolizing the cultural chasm between the characters and the loss of traditional societal values.  
  – This can be seen as an allegory for the destruction of natural beauty and heritage as represented by the strong, young boy who in his recklessness enacts change that is irreversible; the number five (’elima) traditionally symbolizes the five main islands of Hawai'i and can be connecting to broader themes of connectivity and disruption within and among the islands.  
• Overall, this passage highlights the complexities of relationships and the transformative nature of actions in Hawaiian cultural storytelling, serving as a reminder of the intertwined nature of spirituality, physical space, and personal identity in the narrative. It reflects the tension between traditional values, the consequences of individual actions, and the impact of evolving societal norms during the ‘Ai Kapu era and beyond.</commentary>
reference_translation: When Nāmakaokapāo‘o ended his prayer, Puali‘i  struck at Nāmakaokapāo‘o with the adze right on  top of his head, but the blade of the adze turned  towards Puali‘i and his head was cut off. From a  distance, the head of Puali‘i said to   Nāmakaokapāo‘o, “Goodbye, Nāmakaokapāo‘o.”  Nāmakaokapāo‘o took the head of Puali‘i and  threw it in the sea at Waipouli, a cave on the  beach at Honouliuli, which was five miles long.
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 9:**• While the abandonment of the ‘Ai Kapu and the rise  of Christianity are historical, Pua-li‘i’s attack of Nā- maka-o-ka-pāo‘o does not seem to have a correlating  historical reference. The ‘Ai Kapu was abandoned in  1819 and the first Christian missionaries arrived in  Hawai‘i in 1820, with a full year in the interum of no  organized religion to replace the ‘Ai Kapu. While  many Hawaiians were stubbon to adopt Christianity  and resented it, Christianity spread quickly and  overwhelmed any pro-‘Ai Kapu sentiment by the end  of the 1820s. If Pua-li‘i here represents the ‘Ai Kapu  and Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o represents Christianity, and  the adoption of Western culture in a more broad  sense, this event in the story seems to misrepresent  the ‘Ai Kapu as savage, impulsive, and violent against  Christianity, culminating in a single event. There is no  such historical single event recorded in history;  • By a twist of fate, the adze Pua-li‘i wielded to cut off  the head of Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o somehow turned  against the wielder, cutting off the head of Pua-li‘i,  which Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o tossed into the ocean at Wai-pouli (water of darkness), a cave in Hono-uliuli  (bay of darkness) in ‘Ewa, O‘ahu, a distance of five   miles away. This ironic demise of Pua-li‘i signifies the  ultimate defeat of the ‘Ai Kapu by Christianity and/or  progressive ambitions, but this violent event has no  parallel in Hawaiian history. This could be viewed as  an embellishment as a type of Christian progaganda.  • The five-mile long toss of Pua-li‘i’s head by  Nāmakaokapāo‘o was an emphasis on the boy’s  superhuman physical strength.
